messageBody:
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Curt Sampson [mailto:yahoo_sucks@...]
>
> On Sat, 1 Feb 2003, Scott Stirling wrote:
>
> > Again, the simplicity of the code example had nothing to do with the
> > original thread, which was about how to unit test certain predicaments
> > people code themselves into (or inherit from someone else).
>
> I thought I addressed the point quite directly: make this simple change to
> the code and you'll be able to test it easily.

One thing I don't think we ever discussed is the fact that, in the case we
were discussing, the mock object approach allows you to separate your test
from the database connection. I find this extremely useful, and often use
mock objects because they allow me to separate tests from heavy duty
external dependencies like databases and app servers. Mock objects for
common things become extremely useful and wind up being re-used across the
team.

> > > My concern is not about shipping it with the product; my concern is
> > > that, whether it ships or not, it's extra code to write and maintain.
> >
> > Like I said, there's no reason it couldn't be reused.
>
> Sure. But even just doing the setup on that object is still more code
> than simply not testing it.

At this point the discussion turned to not testing the example at all,
rather than which strategy for testing was better. I didn't sign up for
this turn of events. :->

> > "I would predict that the strategy listed above, while good
> > intentioned, on a project of any size would wind up with
> > lots of extra code throughout added just for testability.
>
> It's not lots of extra code. I added, in my example, two extra lines of
> code:

Ha, ha. Again, we are discussing general principles and you retreat to the
particular case. Yes, two lines in this case. But I am trying to analyze
the strategy via the example, not just this example. For the sake of
argument, keep in mind you're going to have a system of 100,000 LOC. Does
adding mixed in methods scale on a large project?

Side note: I think one thing worth pointing out is that any time someone on
this list sends us a method and asks "How the hell do I test this?" they
obviously aren't doing TDD. If they were, they wouldn't have gotten into
that situation in the first place. There are two broad categories of JUnit
users: the TDD and XP folks, and the others who use it as an API and tool
for testing Java, regardless of development methodology. Has nothing to do
with this discussion except as a hint about this problem of "testability"
and my reasons for thinking it should rarely, if ever, be represented as a
method added *only* to make a class testable. I will enumerate some of my
reasons in the separate thread on "Testability."

> I disagree. Maybe it comes from seeing engineers design buildings and
> similar structures: it turns out that you design them not only so that
> they fulfill their intended function after you're done building them,
> but also so that they have good "buildability." They'll add in stuff
> that has no relevance to the final function simply to make it faster,
> cheaper or easier to build. This was a pretty stunning concept to me
> when I first found out about it, because it was something I'd never
> considered before.

Car and motherboard manufacturers do the same thing (Boris Beizer reminds
me). But I'm still interested in the thought process behind testability and
how it impacts object oriented design. We need some principles to guide us.
I mean, hell, you could just as well add a main() method or a test() method
to every class you want to test, but what kind of thinking process is that?
It's certainly not test *first*. I've seen this (the main() method idea)
recommended as a good idea (I think in the 'The Practical Programmer').
Obviously there are benefits to doing your tests in a framework like JUnit,
but there's more to it than just having an API and a test runner and
reporting mechanism. I'm interested in making explicit the thinking that
guides testability. What is "testability?" And what is "maintainability?"
They are similar kinds of things. I am hoping they fall out of good design,
but have yet to prove it.

Scott Stirling
